questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the palatine tonsil is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Crypta magna is a large crypt on the medial surface of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral surface of the tonsil is covered by respiratory epithelium and is adherent to the superior constrictor

options.label: C
options.text: The upper pole of the tonsil is in contact with the tongue and forms the anterior tonsillar space

options.label: D
options.text: The tonsil is anterior to the superior constrictor and lateral to the palatoglossus muscle

questions.correct_answer: A. Crypta magna is a large crypt on the medial surface of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Crypta magna is a large crypt on the medial surface of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crypta magna is the largest crypt on the medial surface of the palatine tonsil and is derived from the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 257
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 257

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the part of the pharynx with its anatomical extent and vertebral level?

options.label: A
options.text: Oropharynx – extends from skull base to soft palate; lies opposite C1

options.label: B
options.text: Laryngopharynx – extends from hyoid to lower border of cricoid; lies opposite C3–C6

options.label: C
options.text: Nasopharynx – extends from soft palate to hyoid bone; lies opposite C2–C3

options.label: D
options.text: Oropharynx – extends from nasal cavity to cricoid cartilage; lies opposite C4–C6

questions.correct_answer: B. Laryngopharynx – extends from hyoid to lower border of cricoid; lies opposite C3–C6
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laryngopharynx – extends from hyoid to lower border of cricoid; lies opposite C3–C6.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The laryngopharynx extends from the hyoid bone to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage and lies opposite vertebrae C3 to C6.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with persistent dull pain in the tonsillar region and upper neck, radiating to the ipsilateral ear. The pain worsens with swallowing. On examination, transoral palpation of the tonsillar fossa elicits tenderness over a bony projection. Lateral skull X-ray reveals an elongated styloid process. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassurance and monitoring with no intervention

options.label: B
options.text: Mandibular nerve block to relieve referred pain

options.label: C
options.text: Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach

options.label: D
options.text: Tonsillectomy to decompress surrounding structures

questions.correct_answer: C. Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eagle syndrome (styalgia) is caused by an elongated styloid process and is treated with surgical excision in symptomatic cases.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 272
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 272

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding nasopharyngeal carcinoma is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The incidence is highest in North India due to widespread air pollution and incense use

options.label: B
options.text: IgA antibodies to EBV viral capsid antigen (VCA) are highly specific for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: Preserved salted fish consumption is a recognized environmental risk factor for NPC due to nitrosamine exposure

options.label: D
options.text: Smoking tobacco is the most important and specific risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma worldwide

questions.correct_answer: C. Preserved salted fish consumption is a recognized environmental risk factor for NPC due to nitrosamine exposure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Preserved salted fish consumption is a recognized environmental risk factor for NPC due to nitrosamine exposure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preserved salted fish containing nitrosamines is a key environmental risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in endemic regions like Southern China and Taiwan.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 250
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 250

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe unilateral sore throat, fever, odynophagia, and difficulty swallowing his saliva. His voice is muffled ("hot potato voice") and he complains of left ear pain. Examination reveals swelling of the left soft palate, deviation of the uvula to the right, and trismus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral penicillin and close outpatient follow-up

options.label: B
options.text: Emergency incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate hot tonsillectomy under general anesthesia

options.label: D
options.text: CT scan of the neck to rule out parapharyngeal abscess

questions.correct_answer: B. Emergency incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritonsillar abscess presents with unilateral sore throat, uvular deviation, trismus, and muffled voice, and is best treated with incision and drainage along with IV antibiotics.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 265
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 265

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It originates from the torus tubarius and grows medially into the nasal septum

options.label: B
options.text: It is a benign tumor composed of vascular spaces with well-developed muscular walls, hence responds well to adrenaline

options.label: C
options.text: It most commonly arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae

options.label: D
options.text: It is a common malignant tumor of the nasopharynx seen in elderly men

questions.correct_answer: C. It most commonly arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It most commonly arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into adjacent fossae, with severe bleeding due to poorly contractile vascular channels.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 246
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 246

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought by his parents with complaints of chronic mouth breathing, snoring, and difficulty hearing. The child has a history of recurrent upper respiratory infections and poor school performance due to inattention. On physical examination, adenoid facies is noted. The physician suspects adenoid hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx

options.label: B
options.text: High-resolution CT scan of the paranasal sinuses

options.label: C
options.text: Diagnostic nasal endoscopy under general anesthesia

options.label: D
options.text: Trial of oral corticosteroids and saline irrigation

questions.correct_answer: A. Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating adenoid hypertrophy and nasopharyngeal airway narrowing in children.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding embryological remnants in the nasopharyngeal region?

options.label: A
options.text: Rathke’s pouch represents notochordal attachment to pharyngeal endoderm and can cause Thornwaldt's disease when infected

options.label: B
options.text: Nasopharyngeal bursa is a remnant of buccal ectoderm and may give rise to craniopharyngioma

options.label: C
options.text: Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass

options.label: D
options.text: Rathke’s pouch lies within the adenoids and connects to the basiocciput through the pharyngeal mucosa

questions.correct_answer: C. Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thornwaldt’s cyst arises from infection of the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant located within the adenoid mass.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 241.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 241.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with high fever, difficulty in swallowing, noisy breathing, and neck stiffness. The child holds the neck in extension with torticollis and has a muffled cry. Examination reveals a unilateral bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall. Lateral neck X-ray shows widening of the prevertebral space. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Emergency tonsillectomy

options.label: B
options.text: CT scan with contrast followed by elective drainage

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and drainage of abscess without anesthesia with suction ready

options.label: D
options.text: Trial of oral antibiotics and observation

questions.correct_answer: C. Incision and drainage of abscess without anesthesia with suction ready
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage of abscess without anesthesia with suction ready

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute retropharyngeal abscess in young children requires immediate incision and drainage without anesthesia, with suction on standby to prevent aspiration.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and soft palate that bleeds on attempted removal. The child has tender cervical lymphadenopathy and early signs of respiratory distress. His neck appears swollen with a "bull-neck" appearance. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Await culture confirmation before initiating antitoxin therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Start erythromycin and antitoxin immediately based on clinical suspicion

options.label: C
options.text: Give IV steroids and nebulized epinephrine for airway edema

options.label: D
options.text: Intubate immediately and refer for surgical debridement of the membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Start erythromycin and antitoxin immediately based on clinical suspicion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start erythromycin and antitoxin immediately based on clinical suspicion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected faucial diphtheria, treatment with antitoxin and antibiotics must be started immediately without waiting for culture confirmation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acute tonsillitis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute catarrhal tonsillitis is usually bacterial and begins with formation of a membrane on the tonsil

options.label: B
options.text: Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at the openings of crypts

options.label: C
options.text: Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis shows purulent material oozing from the crypts without tonsillar enlargement

options.label: D
options.text: Acute membranous tonsillitis is most commonly caused by viral infections in children under 1 year of age

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at the openings of crypts
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at the openings of crypts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at their openings due to accumulation of purulent material.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 259
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 259

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a component of Waldeyer’s ring?

options.label: A
options.text: Tubal tonsils located near the fossa of Rosenmüller

options.label: B
options.text: Palatine tonsils located between the anterior and posterior pillars

options.label: C
options.text: Pharyngeal nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: D
options.text: Piriform sinus mucosa

questions.correct_answer: D. Piriform sinus mucosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Piriform sinus mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Waldeyer’s ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue in the pharynx including adenoids, palatine, lingual, tubal tonsils, lateral bands, and posterior wall nodules—but not the piriform sinus.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with complaints of persistent postnasal drip, nasal obstruction, recurrent sore throat, and dull occipital headaches for the past few months. He also reports intermittent low-grade fever and fullness in the ears. Otoscopy reveals signs of bilateral serous otitis media. On examination of the nasopharynx, a midline cystic swelling with crusting is seen on the posterior wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

options.label: B
options.text: Thornwaldt’s disease

options.label: C
options.text: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Adenoid hypertrophy with chronic rhinitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Thornwaldt’s disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thornwaldt’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thornwaldt’s disease is pharyngeal bursitis caused by infection of a notochordal remnant, presenting with postnasal drip, midline nasopharyngeal swelling, and serous otitis media.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pharyngeal and adjacent anatomical structures is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx

options.label: B
options.text: Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx

options.label: C
options.text: Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones

questions.correct_answer: C. Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius, is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 254
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 254

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with fever, severe sore throat, trismus, and painful swelling just below the angle of the mandible. Examination shows prolapse of the ipsilateral tonsil and deviation of the uvula, with significant odynophagia. He is unable to open his mouth adequately for oropharyngeal examination. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Transoral drainage of the abscess under local anesthesia

options.label: B
options.text: Needle aspiration through the tonsillar fossa to decompress the collection

options.label: C
options.text: Horizontal incision 2–3 cm below the angle of mandible under general anesthesia

options.label: D
options.text: Interval tonsillectomy after initial conservative antibiotic therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Horizontal incision 2–3 cm below the angle of mandible under general anesthesia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Horizontal incision 2–3 cm below the angle of mandible under general anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parapharyngeal abscess is drained by a horizontal external incision below the mandible; transoral drainage is contraindicated due to risk of vascular injury.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 268
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 268

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a known diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) presents with nasal obstruction, profuse recurrent epistaxis, and left facial swelling. CT imaging shows extension of the mass into the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae, without intracranial extension. The patient underwent successful preoperative embolization. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start high-dose corticosteroids and observe for regression

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic surgical excision within 24–48 hours of embolization

options.label: C
options.text: Plan radiotherapy to the nasopharynx to achieve long-term regression

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate androgen-blocking therapy with flutamide to shrink the tumor

questions.correct_answer: B. Endoscopic surgical excision within 24–48 hours of embolization
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic surgical excision within 24–48 hours of embolization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical resection within 24–48 hours after preoperative embolization is the treatment of choice for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma without intracranial extension.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 249
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 249

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent sore throat, bad breath, and night-time choking episodes for the past several months. Examination reveals enlarged tonsils meeting at midline, yellowish beads on the tonsillar surface, and flushing of anterior pillars. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are palpable bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassurance and warm saline gargles

options.label: B
options.text: Start a course of antibiotics for 10 days

options.label: C
options.text: Schedule for elective tonsillectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a throat swab for bacterial culture before proceeding

questions.correct_answer: C. Schedule for elective tonsillectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schedule for elective tonsillectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tonsillectomy is indicated in chronic tonsillitis with recurrent infections, obstructive symptoms, and significant tonsillar hypertrophy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with fever, difficulty swallowing, neck stiffness, and stridor. Examination reveals a unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. Imaging confirms a deep neck space infection. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the anatomical location and implications of this infection?

options.label: A
options.text: It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and extends from skull base to coccyx

options.label: B
options.text: It is located between buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, and may spread to the mediastinum

options.label: C
options.text: It is separated by a vertical midline raphe into symmetrical prevertebral compartments

options.label: D
options.text: It usually arises from tuberculosis of the cervical spine and presents with bilateral bulging of the pharynx

questions.correct_answer: B. It is located between buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, and may spread to the mediastinum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is located between buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, and may spread to the mediastinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The retropharyngeal space lies between the buccopharyngeal and prevertebral fascia, extends to the tracheal bifurcation, and infections here can spread to the mediastinum.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 266
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 266

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with a foreign body sensation in the throat, pricking pain during swallowing, and referred earache. Examination reveals a fixed neck mass in the upper cervical region, but no hoarseness or obvious mass in the oropharynx. Indirect laryngoscopy shows pooling of secretions in the left pyriform sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which of the following statements is most accurate regarding management?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyriform sinus carcinoma; radiotherapy is preferred even in large tumors with nodal involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Pyriform sinus carcinoma; cervical lymph node metastasis is rare and late in disease course

options.label: C
options.text: Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease

options.label: D
options.text: Postcricoid carcinoma; surgical excision is rarely used due to anatomical inaccessibility

questions.correct_answer: C. Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyriform sinus carcinoma commonly presents late with early nodal spread, and localized disease is treated with laryngectomy, partial pharyngectomy, and neck dissection.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 273
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 273

questions.text: Which of the following statements about retropharyngeal space and abscess is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It lies anterior to the buccopharyngeal fascia and contains the space of Gillette

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is commonly due to tuberculosis secondary to Pott’s spine

options.label: C
options.text: The retropharyngeal space is undivided and contains a single large midline lymph node

options.label: D
options.text: Retropharyngeal abscess causes a midline bulge and is best diagnosed by CT scan of the brain

questions.correct_answer: B. Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is commonly due to tuberculosis secondary to Pott’s spine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is commonly due to tuberculosis secondary to Pott’s spine

  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 247.

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-operative patient develops fever, swelling, and tenderness at the angle of the mandible on the fifth day after abdominal surgery. The swelling is erythematous, indurated, and mildly fluctuant. The patient is dehydrated and toxic. On oral examination, pressure over the swelling leads to pus exuding from the Stenson's duct. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV antibiotics and monitor for spontaneous drainage

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate incision and drainage via a submandibular approach

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate IV fluids and antibiotics, followed by surgical drainage via a preauricular incision

options.label: D
options.text: Refer for emergency superficial parotidectomy

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate IV fluids and antibiotics, followed by surgical drainage via a preauricular incision
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Initiate IV fluids and antibiotics, followed by surgical drainage via a preauricular incision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parotid abscess in dehydrated patients requires IV fluids, antibiotics, and surgical drainage via a preauricular incision parallel to the facial nerve branches.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 263
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 263

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia and occasional spitting of blood. Examination reveals no intraoral lesions, but a firm, bilateral upper deep cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a midline exophytic lesion over the posterior pharyngeal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis and best initial step for further evaluation?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior pharyngeal wall carcinoma; proceed with endoscopy and biopsy

options.label: B
options.text: Postcricoid carcinoma; perform CT scan and barium swallow

options.label: C
options.text: Laryngeal carcinoma; schedule microlaryngoscopy for biopsy

options.label: D
options.text: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma; perform MRI of skull base and neck

questions.correct_answer: A. Posterior pharyngeal wall carcinoma; proceed with endoscopy and biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior pharyngeal wall carcinoma; proceed with endoscopy and biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carcinoma of the posterior pharyngeal wall presents with dysphagia and bilateral cervical nodes and is confirmed by endoscopic biopsy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent, spontaneous episodes of profuse epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction. His voice has become denasal, and he complains of hearing difficulty. On examination, a purplish lobulated mass is seen filling the nasopharynx and obstructing the choanae. Otoscopy shows a dull tympanic membrane suggestive of middle ear effusion. CT scan of the head reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform endoscopic biopsy of the lesion in the outpatient setting

options.label: B
options.text: Plan for CT-guided excision after confirming diagnosis with nasal swab cytology

options.label: C
options.text: Perform carotid angiography with embolization followed by surgical resection

options.label: D
options.text: Start high-dose corticosteroids to reduce the vascularity of the lesion

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform carotid angiography with embolization followed by surgical resection
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is diagnosed clinically and radiologically; biopsy is avoided, and pre-operative carotid angiography with embolization is essential before surgical resection.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of unilateral nasal obstruction, serous otitis media, and a painless neck swelling. He also reports recent onset of facial pain and diplopia. Nasal endoscopy reveals a submucosal mass in the nasopharynx. Biopsy is planned. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to assess both the extent of the primary tumor and skull base involvement before treatment planning?

options.label: A
options.text: Chest X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasopharynx and neck

options.label: C
options.text: PET-CT scan

options.label: D
options.text: Pure tone audiogram

questions.correct_answer: B. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasopharynx and neck
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasopharynx and neck

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Contrast-enhanced CT of the nasopharynx and neck is the preferred imaging for evaluating the local extent, bony invasion, and nodal status in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 252
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 252

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the structure of the pharyngeal wall is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The mucous membrane of the pharynx is entirely lined by stratified squamous epithelium

options.label: B
options.text: The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thickest inferiorly and merges with the esophageal wall

options.label: C
options.text: The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles

options.label: D
options.text: The buccopharyngeal fascia lies internal to the pharyngeal aponeurosis and lines the mucosal surface

questions.correct_answer: C. The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pharyngeal wall has a muscular coat with an external constrictor layer and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles (stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, and palatopharyngeus).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is diagnosed with a nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The tumor extends into the oropharynx with parapharyngeal space involvement. There is bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, each node measuring less than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and no evidence of distant metastasis. Based on the TNM classification, what is the clinical stage of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Stage IIB

options.label: B
options.text: Stage III

options.label: C
options.text: Stage IVA

options.label: D
options.text: Stage IVB

questions.correct_answer: B. Stage III
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ T2bN2M0 nasopharyngeal carcinoma (parapharyngeal extension with bilateral nodes <6 cm) is classified as Stage III.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, gurgling sounds on swallowing, foul breath, and occasional regurgitation of undigested food, especially at night. He reports a chronic cough and has lost significant weight over the past few months. A barium swallow reveals a posterior midline outpouching at the level of the pharyngoesophageal junction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Upper GI endoscopy and biopsy

options.label: B
options.text: Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision

options.label: C
options.text: Proton pump inhibitor therapy with lifestyle modification

options.label: D
options.text: Feeding jejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and gurgling, and is treated by cricopharyngeal myotomy with excision of the pouch.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the floor of the mouth, difficulty swallowing, and progressive trismus for the past 2 days. He has poor dental hygiene and recently had a painful lower molar. On examination, there is bilateral submandibular swelling, firm, woody induration, and elevation of the tongue. He appears toxic and has stridor. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical exploration and incision of the submental space

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain dental consultation and start oral antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Secure the airway and start IV antibiotics urgently

options.label: D
options.text: Incise the sublingual space via intraoral route under local anesthesia

questions.correct_answer: C. Secure the airway and start IV antibiotics urgently
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Secure the airway and start IV antibiotics urgently

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ludwig’s angina is a potentially life-threatening cellulitis of the submandibular space, and securing the airway with IV antibiotics is the first priority in management.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 264
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 264

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of high-grade fever, sore throat, and refusal to eat for the past 2 days. The mother also reports bad breath and occasional abdominal pain. On examination, the child has coated tongue, fetid breath, enlarged congested tonsils with yellow spots on their surface, and tender jugulodigastric lymphadenopathy. A diagnosis of acute follicular tonsillitis is made. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Ciprofloxacin

options.label: B
options.text: Erythromycin for 2 days followed by supportive care

options.label: C
options.text: Paracetamol and penicillin for 7–10 days

options.label: D
options.text: Tonsillectomy in acute setting to relieve symptoms immediately

questions.correct_answer: C. Paracetamol and penicillin for 7–10 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paracetamol and penicillin for 7–10 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute follicular tonsillitis is treated with analgesics and a 7–10 day course of penicillin; erythromycin is used in penicillin-allergic patients.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 259
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 259

questions.text: A 48-year-old man diagnosed with stage III nasopharyngeal carcinoma undergoes staging workup showing no distant metastases. The tumor involves the parapharyngeal space with multiple ipsilateral cervical nodes. He is otherwise healthy with good performance status. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment plan for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) alone

options.label: B
options.text: Concomitant chemoradiotherapy with cisplatin

options.label: C
options.text: Radical neck dissection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic nasopharyngectomy followed by brachytherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Concomitant chemoradiotherapy with cisplatin
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Concomitant chemoradiotherapy with cisplatin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Concomitant chemoradiotherapy with cisplatin is the treatment of choice for stage III and IV nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 252
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 252

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric ENT clinic with complaints of persistent mouth breathing, difficulty feeding, and poor weight gain. The mother notes that the child often has a wet, runny nose and tends to speak in a toneless voice. On examination, the child has an elongated face, open mouth posture, pinched-in nose, prominent upper teeth, and a highly arched palate. Tympanic membranes appear retracted bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Congenital choanal atresia

options.label: B
options.text: Allergic rhinitis with secondary maxillary sinusitis

options.label: C
options.text: Adenoid hypertrophy with eustachian tube obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: Primary ciliary dyskinesia

questions.correct_answer: C. Adenoid hypertrophy with eustachian tube obstruction
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenoid hypertrophy with eustachian tube obstruction

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy can cause nasal obstruction, recurrent otitis media, hearing loss, and characteristic adenoid facies in children.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 244
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 244

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Zenker’s diverticulum is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It arises through Killian’s dehiscence, located between the superior and middle constrictors

options.label: B
options.text: It commonly presents with halitosis, gurgling sounds, and right-sided neck swelling

options.label: C
options.text: It is most commonly seen in individuals below 40 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: It occurs through a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor

questions.correct_answer: D. It occurs through a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It occurs through a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum arises through Killian’s dehiscence—between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 243.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 243.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the parapharyngeal space is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is located between the pharynx and the sternocleidomastoid muscle and extends from the hyoid bone to the clavicle

options.label: B
options.text: Pre-styloid compartment lies medial to the tonsil and contains cranial nerves IX to XII

options.label: C
options.text: Post-styloid compartment contains the carotid sheath and its contents, and a mass here causes medial bulge behind the posterior pillar

options.label: D
options.text: Pre-styloid compartment contains facial nerve and submandibular gland and a mass here causes bulge in anterior triangle of neck

questions.correct_answer: C. Post-styloid compartment contains the carotid sheath and its contents, and a mass here causes medial bulge behind the posterior pillar
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Post-styloid compartment contains the carotid sheath and its contents, and a mass here causes medial bulge behind the posterior pillar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space contains the carotid sheath and causes a medial pharyngeal bulge behind the posterior tonsillar pillar when involved.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding deep neck spaces and fasciae is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The danger space lies between the buccopharyngeal and prevertebral fascia and extends up to the coccyx

options.label: B
options.text: Retropharyngeal space lies behind the alar fascia and contains the danger space

options.label: C
options.text: The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends inferiorly up to T4

options.label: D
options.text: Prevertebral space lies between the alar and buccopharyngeal fasciae and terminates at the mediastinum

questions.correct_answer: C. The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends inferiorly up to T4
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends inferiorly up to T4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends from skull base to T4 and can spread infection to the mediastinum.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6 th Edition, pg 248.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6 th Edition, pg 248.

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles of the pharynx?

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild dysphagia, posterior throat discomfort, and a gradually enlarging midline swelling on the posterior pharyngeal wall. He also has multiple cervical lymph nodes and a history of weight loss and low-grade fever. Cervical spine X-ray reveals destruction of C3 and C4 vertebral bodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: IV antibiotics and emergency incision and drainage

options.label: B
options.text: Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Oral steroids and observation

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate tracheostomy to prevent airway obstruction

questions.correct_answer: B. Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic retropharyngeal abscess due to cervical spine tuberculosis is treated with incision and drainage followed by a full course of antitubercular therapy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a foreign body sensation in the throat and halitosis. On examination, a gritty mass is felt on probing the tonsil. There is no fever, dysphagia, or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Tonsillar cyst

options.label: B
options.text: Tonsillolith

options.label: C
options.text: Intratonsillar abscess

options.label: D
options.text: Peritonsillar abscess

questions.correct_answer: B. Tonsillolith
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tonsillolith

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tonsilloliths present with halitosis and a foreign body sensation and are diagnosed by a gritty feel on probing the tonsil.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 261
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 261

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with low-grade fever and a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and soft palate. The membrane is adherent and bleeds on attempted removal. There is mild sore throat, and urine analysis reveals albuminuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute membranous tonsillitis

options.label: B
options.text: Diphtheria

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Infectious mononucleosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Diphtheria
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Diphtheria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria presents with an adherent, dirty grey membrane over the tonsils and soft palate that bleeds on removal and is confirmed by detection of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and diplopia. Imaging reveals a mass in the nasopharynx with extension into the orbit and skull base. Clinical examination shows bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, each node less than 6 cm, with no distant metastasis. What is the correct clinical stage of this patient’s nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Stage III

options.label: B
options.text: Stage IVA

options.label: C
options.text: Stage IVB

options.label: D
options.text: Stage IVC

questions.correct_answer: B. Stage IVA
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage IVA

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ T4N2M0 nasopharyngeal carcinoma is classified as Stage IVA due to intracranial and orbital involvement with bilateral lymph node metastasis and no distant spread.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with progressive left-sided hearing loss and a painless neck lump just below the angle of the mandible. He also reports intermittent nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis. Otoscopy reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane. Neurological examination reveals decreased corneal reflex on the left and mild weakness of left lateral gaze. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma

options.label: B
options.text: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

options.label: C
options.text: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Glomus jugulare tumor

questions.correct_answer: C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma commonly presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, unilateral serous otitis media, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cranial nerve palsies due to skull base extension.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 251

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and a history of iron-deficiency anemia. She has no significant smoking or alcohol history. Indirect laryngoscopy does not reveal any mass, but pooling of secretions is noted in the hypopharynx. Barium swallow reveals an irregular narrowing in the postcricoid region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is an important associated risk factor?

options.label: A
options.text: Carcinoma of the upper esophagus; associated with Barrett's esophagus

options.label: B
options.text: Carcinoma of the pyriform sinus; associated with heavy smoking and alcohol use

options.label: C
options.text: Carcinoma of the postcricoid region; associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Carcinoma of the larynx; associated with vocal abuse and laryngopharyngeal reflux

questions.correct_answer: C. Carcinoma of the postcricoid region; associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carcinoma of the postcricoid region; associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carcinoma of the postcricoid region is strongly associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome and presents with progressive dysphagia, especially in young females.
